contentrichtext.text: The '''Presidential Cup Game''' (also known as the '''Presidential Cup Bowl''') was a postseason [[American football|American]] [[college football]] bowl game played at [[Byrd Stadium]] in [[College Park, Maryland]], on December 9, 1950 between Texas A&M University and University of Georgia.<ref>Foldesy, Jody. "Bowls burgeon as big business", ''The Washington Times''. December 21, 1997. Page A1.</ref> ==Entering the game== The Aggies, coached by [[Harry Stiteler]], entered the contest with a 6-4 record. A&M had posted victories over Nevada, Texas Tech, VMI, TCU, Arkansas, and SMU; while dropping contests against Oklahoma, Baylor, Rice, and Texas. The game was A&M's first post-season appearance since a 19-14 defeat at the hands of LSU in the 1944 Orange Bowl. Having posted records of 0-9-1 and 1-8-1 in his first two seasons in College Station, the 1950 season marked a huge turn-around for Stiteler's program. The victory over Georgia, however, was to mark the end of his tenure at A&M. Meanwhile in Athens, Coach Wally Butts' Bulldogs had scratched out a 6-2-3 record. The Red & Black enjoyed victories over Maryland, Mississippi State, Boston College, Florida, Auburn, and Furman; fought to ties with Saint Mary's, North Carolina, and LSU; and lost 14-7 against Alabama, and 7-0 to Georgia Tech. The trip to College Park was Georgia's 7th bowl venture, and would be UGA's first December bowl outing. ==Game result== {| border="1" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="0" !bgcolor="#e5e5e5"| Date Played !! colspan="2" bgcolor="#e5e5e5"| Winning Team !! colspan="2" bgcolor="#e5e5e5"| Losing Team !! bgcolor="#e5e5e5"| Location |- | December 9, 1950 || '''[[Texas A&M University|Texas A&M]]'''|| '''40'''|| [[University of Georgia|Georgia]] || 20 || [[College Park, Maryland]] |} ==See also== [[List of college bowl games]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Georgia Bulldogs bowl game navbox}} {{Texas A&M Aggies bowl game navbox}} [[Category:1950 NCAA football season]] [[Category:Defunct college football bowls]]
